text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.25.12, Estate and Gift Tax, Valuation Assistance.
IRM 4.25.12.5, Economist Referrals, was obsoleted. Economist referral requirements and report writing procedures are located in IRM 4.61.3.
This material supersedes the July 19, 2018 published version of IRM
This section contains instructions and guidelines for Small Business/Self-Employed Estate and Gift Tax Specialty Programs employees.
Table of Contents
) General Overview - This IRM provides information about the valuation tance services utilized by Estate and Gift examiners to determine the fair and market value of property. (

) Purpose - This IRM explains the processes and procedures used by Estate and Gift examiners to obtain asset valuation assistance so that managers, senior-level officials, and estate, gift and generation-skipping transfer tax examiners will be better equipped to prepare and submit accurate reports. (

) Audience - This IRM is for Estate and Gift Specialty Tax managers, and personnel at the campus who examine and process estate, gift and generation-skipping transfer tax returns, refunds and claims. (

) Policy Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Policy, is responsible for administration, procedures and updates related to the technical guidance information processing steps and methods speciﬁc to Estate and Gift Tax examiner responsibilities, IRM subsections, and forms created for the tion of returns and claims. (
) Program Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Examination owns and Gift Tax Examination. (

) Primary Stakeholders - Advisory Collections, Appeals, Art Appraisal Counsel, Estate and Gift Tax Workload Selection and Delivery, Specialty Ex- amination, and SB/SE Examination Quality & Technical Support are the primary stakeholders for this IRM. (

) IRM text provides to Estate and Gift Tax examination speciﬁc procedures for obtaining real and intangible property valuation assistance. This IRM direction which is Estate and Gift Tax speciﬁc. These procedures and do not apply to Excise or Excise-fuel examinations. (

) Estate and gift tax examiners and managers assigned to examine and the examination of estate and gift tax returns and issues are responsible for complying with servicewide policies and authorities set forth in IRM
, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policy Statements for the Examining Process. (
) Examination of estate and gift tax returns should be conducted in a manner that will promote public conﬁdence as stated in the Mission of the Service. IRM
, Policy Statement

months of the ﬁling See IRM

) The National Quality Review System (NQRS) is a web-based review used by Estate and Gift Tax Policy, Estate and Gift Tax Examination ment and Estate and Gift Tax Quality Measures and Analysis (QMA) to generate and review reports analyzing national quality performance based upon standardized quality attributes set forth in Document

, Estate Gift Tax Examination Embedded Quality Job Aid. NQRS report data is compiled by QMA on a quarterly basis, but ad hoc reports may be monthly. The use of NQRS is explained in additional detail in IRM
, Manager Embedded Quality Review and Specialty Exam National Quality Review Programs. (

) Operational Reviews and related NQRS reports are conducted by Territory Managers and the Chief of Estate and Gift to measure national adherence quality standards and managerial performance and/or oversight. (

) Customer (i.e. taxpayer) satisfaction reports are generated by SB/SE Operation Support Research on a quarterly basis. These reports provide masked taxpayer narratives that are responsive to a pre-deﬁned set of questions. The quarterly survey reports are to be used to identify areas for amination quality improvement. (
) Frequent Front-line manager reviews are conducted under the Examination Quality Review System (EQRS), with the frequency based on annual personnel requirements. (

, Appeals, Valuation Assistance, Valuation Assistance dures (Art Appraisal Services) (

) The Specialist Referral System (SRS) automates the specialist referral process. A referral can be generated online which will automatically notify appropriate Specialist Manager by e-mail of the request. The manager can evaluate the referral and determine if it will be assigned, rejected or trans- ferred. If assigned, a specialist is then notiﬁed by e-mail of the assignment and can initiate communication with the requestor. A conforming copy of the referral will be e-mailed to both the examiner requesting the referral and to examiner’s group manager. (
) Examiners may use SRS to obtain assistance from Art Appraisal Services, LB&I Engineers and Economists. (
) Examiners requesting a Specialist do not need any special permission to access SRS. (

) The Office of Art Appraisal Services (AAS) (under the Chief of Appeals) provides valuation assistance concerning works of art and cultural property. to addition, it administers and consults with the Commissioner’s Art Advisory Panel (Art Panel), a group of nationally prominent art museum curators, scholars, and art dealers chosen to assist the Service in the appraisal of of art. Items appropriate for AAS review include paintings, drawings, prints, sculptures, antiques, ceramics, photographs, furniture, textiles, carpets, books, glass, coins, rare manuscripts and historical memorabilia. (
) IRM
, Art Appraisal Services Referral Procedures, provides for requesting art valuation assistance. (

) All referrals made to AAS must be made using the Specialist Referral (SRS). The examiner must include a copy of the SRS referral in the IMS ﬁle. The examiner must also include a copy of the SRS referral in the hard copy case ﬁle if the case is closed unagreed. (
) Material in support of referrals, such as appraisals, photographs, etc., should be provided to the assigned appraiser, using encrypted email or sent using UPS ground. (

) Prior to any formal referral, examiners may contact the AAS for any advice preliminary assistance. Questions should be submitted using the SRS “Comments” box to facilitate tracking and assignment of questions within Additional internal resource are available on the AAS’ web page.

) The Specialist Referral System (SRS) automates the specialist referral process. A referral can be generated online which will automatically notify the appropriate Specialist Manager by e-mail of the request. The manager can evaluate the referral and determine if it will be assigned, rejected or trans- ferred. If assigned, a specialist is then notiﬁed by e-mail of the assignment and can initiate communication with the requestor. A conforming copy of the referral will be e-mailed to both the examiner requesting the referral and to the examiner’s group manager.

page (
) If an examiner has a return under examination that involves a taxpayer’s appraisal of a work of art with a claimed value of $

or more, it must be referred to Art Appraisal Services (AAS) for review by the Commissioner’s Art Advisory Panel (Art Panel) when applicable. AAS may consult with the Art Panel for advisory opinions on value in twice annual meetings. (

) Exception: Referrals are not required for estate or gift tax cases in which of art do not form part of the tax base because they pass (or are deemed to pass) to a surviving spouse or to a qualiﬁed charity or in matters involving taxable returns that are not likely to result in deﬁciencies. Where referrals would otherwise be required and, due to the application of these exceptions other considerations (for example, risk analysis) they are not made, tation of the applicable exception or analysis must be included in the ﬁle with an indication of concurrence by the group manager. See IRM
, nation Techniques, Risk Analysis and IRM
, Risk Analysis. (
) In cases with art work or an art appraisal identiﬁed on the classiﬁcation group managers will assign (or survey before assignment) cases within
days of receipt. (
) Examiners will make a referral to AAS within
days of receipt of the case from the group manager, if the case will be examined and includes a piece of art with a returned value of $
or more and all required information for the referral is contained in the ﬁle. If all required information for the referral is not in the ﬁle, a document request must be made within
days of and documented in the ﬁle. (
) The referral must adhere to the requirements set forth by AAS pursuant to
, Valuation Assistance for Cases Involving Works of Art, and IRM Valuation Assistance Procedures, including the required use of the Specialist Referral System (SRS). (
) When submitting items to AAS for valuation review, refer to IRM

, Art Appraisal Services Referral Procedures, for links to a complete listing of required items and information. All required information, including complete praisals in color and color photographs, should be assembled before making the SRS request for valuation assistance. To allow AAS time to prepare for Art Panel review, submissions for the Spring meeting should be received January
and submissions for the Fall meeting should be received by June

Please allow ample time for an AAS review considering the Art Panel only meets twice annually and AAS appraisers conduct extensive research and write professional appraisal reports. Submissions to AAS should be made as early in the audit as possible to allow for a typical AAS review, which may
months depending upon number of items and complexity. Please call Director of AAS or the Lead Appraiser prior to making an SRS request for referrals of cases which have less than
months left on the statute. (

) If agreement cannot be reached with the taxpayer, further assistance may be requested of AAS. Taxpayers may request an Appraisal Reconsideration of a proposed valuation adjustment by AAS only if they submit a request in writing which includes substantial evidence which will affect the valuation of the item(s) to support their fair market value opinion. Further, their request must respond speciﬁcally to the report issued by AAS. See IRM
, Art Advisory Panel and IRM
, Reconsideration and Dispute Procedures. the valuation issue is not ultimately resolved between the taxpayer and AAS

If an examiner has a return under examination that involves a taxpayer’s appraisal of a work of art with a claimed value of $50,000 or more, it must be referred to Art Appraisal Services (AAS) for review by the Commissioner’s Art Advisory Panel (Art Panel) when applicable. AAS may consult with the Art Panel for advisory opinions on value in twice annual meetings.
and the taxpayer chooses to pursue resolution through participation in Fast Track Settlement, AAS will also participate in this process. See IRM Fast Track Settlement. (

Many engineers have credentials or certiﬁcations technical and valuation areas beyond their formal education. These or certiﬁcations were earned from nationally recognized professional associa- tions such as appraisal societies, and societies of professional scientists, foresters and engineers.

to determine if the fair market value of an asset reported on an estate or gift tax return, and any applicable discounts, are reasonable under the circum- stances. The referral may include a request for various types of assistance ranging from a consultation to a valuation appraisal report. Note: While IRM
recommends referrals of real property assets with a minimum fair market value of $

, there are no minimum or dollar thresholds requirements for making an engineering referral. Note: For personal property art assets valued on the return, the Art Appraisal guideline referral process in IRM
should be followed. All other personal property referrals should be made after conducting a risk See IRM

) Requests for engineer assistance must be made through the Specialist ral System (SRS). This includes consultation services for assistance. The is an online automated system that allows for submissions and approvals for specialist assistance. It automates the referral request process. SRS is ac- cessed from the intranet at SRS Referral. When an online request is submit- ted, SRS automatically notiﬁes the appropriate specialist manager of the request. The system is web-enabled and can provide management information reports of Engineer resources utilized by Estate and Gift. The ex- aminer will include a copy of the SRS referral in both the hard copy and IMS case ﬁle. (

) Engineer resources are available on a national basis. The engineer manager will attempt to seek assistance from other engineer teams to provide the needed expertise in situations where the locally available engineer staff does not have a required specialist in a particular ﬁeld. Therefore, Estate and Gift groups should submit referrals if needed whether or not they believe there sufficient engineering resources which can be allocated to their cases. (

) During the assignment of a case, the group manager may determine that a valuation issue exists that warrants a referral for engineering assistance. In situation, the group manager will annotate the case accordingly by providing instructions to the examiner as to the scope of the proposed referral. (

) Examiners may forgo an engineering referral of a classiﬁed valuation issue managerial selected issue. Documentation of the examiner’s decision must included in the case ﬁle. This decision may be based on a number of risk analysis factors. See IRM
, Examination Techniques, Risk Analysis IRM
, Risk Analysis. (

) If an examiner makes the determination during the planning phase that a referral is needed, managerial approval must be obtained prior to submitting request for engineering assistance. The examiner should document the eration of the referral in the workpapers or lead sheets. (
) If a case is referred, a copy of the referral must be included in the IMS case ﬁle. The referral must also be in the hard copy case ﬁle if the case is closed unagreed. Internal Revenue Manual

Estate and Gift (
) A Form
, Transmittal Document, should be used when providing the engineer hardcopy information. (
) When an engineer is involved in a case, the examiner maintains control of return and its management. The engineer is added as a Team Member on for the issue assigned. (

) Engineer(s) assigned to the case should meet with the examiner to discuss issue, scope of services to be provided, information required, time-frames for information to be requested, estimated time to be charged to the case, and estimated date for the completion of the referral. This information is docu- mented and supported by the Engagement Letter, the initial Case Status Report, the engineer’s workpapers, correspondence with the engineer, and engineer’s Activity Record. (
) The Engagement Letter will be issued by the engineer no later than
days from the assignment of the referral to the engineer and it will include the date that the referral was made. The examiner will document receipt of the ment Letter on the Form
, Activity Record. (

) The examiner will prepare the initial Case Status Report and add it to IMS. engineer will use the report to provide a monthly status report to the The Case Status Report template can be accessed via the Estate and Gift LB intranet websites. (

) Continued cooperation with the engineer is required to ensure issues are material to the return and time charged commensurate with the issue. This ordination will be documented on the monthly Case Status Report and the activity record. (
) The engineer will serve as a technical consultant and will be available to the examiner in meetings with the taxpayer (when appropriate) for case tion. (
) Disagreement on proposed adjustments between the examiner and engineer specialist should be elevated to their respective managers for resolution. (
) Estate and Gift group managers/delegated support staff should verify that spent to work the issue by the engineer (including travel time) is properly accounted for on ERCS. (
) The engineer specialist’s examination plan, activity record and work product documentation must be included in the examiner’s case ﬁle on IMS. (
) Ongoing risk analysis discussions should be held between the examiner and the assigned engineering referral staff. Engineering’s process for risk analysis is described at IRM

, Pre-Examination Activity. The examiner will work with the engineer to compare the beneﬁts and prioritize issues. The examiner is responsible for providing clear instructions regarding the scope of the referral and explaining any legal issues that should be taken into ation as part of the valuation analysis.
The engineer will serve as a technical consultant and will be available to assist the examiner in meetings with the taxpayer (when appropriate) for case resolu-
on proposed adjustments between the examiner and engineer should be elevated to their respective managers for resolution.
The engineer specialist’s examination plan, activity record and work product documentation must be included in the examiner’s case ﬁle on IMS.
page (
) An S Corporation is a domestic business entity that is treated as a for Federal tax purposes. The corporation made an election under IRC to be governed by Subchapter S of the Code. See IRC
through IRC

In actual form, such an entity may be a state-chartered corporation or an unincorporated entity, such as a limited liability company. Subchapter S places limitations on such things as the number and the type of owners (interest holders) and the number of classes of stock. Generally, electing S Corporations pay no entity level Federal taxes on their income. Instead, the income and deductions of the entity ﬂow through to the interest holders who are responsible for their appropriate share of the entity’s Federal income tax liability, in a manner similar to partnership taxation models. Electing S rations may still be responsible for State and/or local income or franchise taxes. (
) Electing S Corporations are subject to the same valuation considerations that are applicable to any closely held business entity. Valuation guidance is set forth by Rev. Rul.

Given the organizational structure necessary to conform to Subchapter S, as opposed to that of otherwise similar business entities, potential differences in such things as the cost of capital the marketability of non-controlling interests must be addressed. (

) Absent a compelling showing that unrelated parties dealing at arms-length would reduce the projected cash ﬂows on an S Corporation by a hypothetical entity level tax, no entity level tax should be applied in determining the cash ﬂows of an electing S Corporation. See Valuation of Non-Controlling in Business Entities Electing to be Treated as S Corporations for Federal Tax Purposes, A Job Aid for IRS Valuation Analysts for additional information re- garding the valuation of S Corporation interests. (

) Prior to referring the S Corporation valuation issue to engineering, the examiner should review the formation and entity governance documentation, previous tax return ﬁlings and the taxpayer’s appraisal(s) to determine the payer’s valuation method. Upon completion of this review, the examiner is responsible for setting the scope of the valuation referral and providing tions to the engineer regarding what entity level taxation should be applied, if any. See Gross v. Commissioner, T.C. Memo
, aff’d

) The Outside Fee Appraisal (OFA) process provides access to outside on a contract fee basis for Estate and/or Gift Tax cases. (

) The Territory Manager should consider program priorities and evaluate case needs and compliance impact when approving the use of OFA funds. Consid- eration will also be given to available in-house/Service expertise and the timeline for service delivery. In-house/Service expertise includes all qualiﬁed IRS experts including engineers, valuation specialists, and economists. (
) Territory Managers will be authorized to approve requests for an OFA where the estimated cost is less than $
; funding priorities are determined by the Chief, Estate and Gift Tax program, and funding of the approved requests will be determined by the Chief. Internal Revenue Manual

on a contract fee basis for Estate and/or Gift Tax cases. The Territory Manager should consider program priorities and evaluate case needs and compliance impact when approving the use of OFA funds. Consid- eration will also be given to available in-house/Service expertise and the timeline for service delivery. In-house/Service expertise includes all qualiﬁed IRS experts including engineers, valuation specialists, and economists. Territory Managers will be authorized to approve requests for an OFA where the estimated cost is less than $
; funding priorities are determined by the Chief, Estate and Gift Tax program, and funding of the approved requests
) Requisitions with a total estimated cost of $

or more should include a written recommendation from Counsel and/or local Engineering This recommendation should explain why either or both of these support the use of an outside expert rather than the use of in-house experts. Counsel and/or Engineering involvement and support for requisitions with a total cost of less than $
are also recommended. (

) The Estate and Gift Tax OFA Funding Application and Mandatory Feedback Form (OFA Feedback Form) is required to provide uniformity and tion of the factors considered in the requisition and approval process. Determination and documentation of whether qualiﬁed in-house expertise is being utilized is a minimum requirement for all requisitions. The OFA Form can be found on the Estate and Gift Website. (

) The preparation of the OFA form should be a team effort with Engineering Counsel’s involvement documented. The Examination Team should work closely with the Technical Advisor to the Chief in preparing the OFA form to submitting the OFA for approval. Copies of the OFA form relating to an approved request should be maintained by the appropriate Territory Manager as a matter of internal control and documentation. A copy of this form must provided to the Technical Advisor to the Chief prior to any RTS submission. (

) Once the OFA is approved, the Examination Team and the COR will work closely with the Technical Advisor to the Chief to ensure the proper of work is drafted, including Area Counsel’s agreement to the description of property rights being valued, the date of valuation, and any alternative rights or valuation methods to consider. (
) Results must be captured on the OFA form and a complete copy of the form provided to the Technical Advisor to the Chief no later than

days following case closure. This is necessary to provide essential information to manage- ment for analysis, to achieve effective utilization of OFA funds in the future to justify additional funding, if warranted. (

) The Technical Advisor to the Chief will monitor all expenditures and results will maintain a contemporaneous decision point spreadsheet available at all time for use by Chief, Estate and Gift Tax Program, in making funding nations.
